Nature's first born, hail to thee,</br>Rustic Nymph, Simplicity!</br>Drest in robes of russet gray,</br>Sprightly as the month of May:</br>Fairer than the Graces three,</br>Rural Goddess, hail to thee!</br>Come, and smiling bring with thee</br>Mildly blushing Modesty:</br>Innocence with brow serene;</br>Rosy Health, the woodland Queen:</br>Calm Content, with chearful air:</br>Piety, the heaven-born fair:</br>Virtuous Love, devoid of guile,</br>Tripping on with infant smile;</br>Blessing on the happy plains,</br>Artless nymphs, and constant swains:</br>Votaries true to Love and thee,</br>Rural Queen, Simplicity!

Goddess come; and sit with me</br>Underneath some aged tree;</br>Listening to the woodlark's lay,</br>Sweetly warbling on the spray;</br>Or the milkmaid in the dale,</br>Tripping on with brimming pail;</br>Whilst her swain, with eager feet,</br>Hastes his much-lov'd fair to meet;</br>Now he bears her frothing pail,</br>Jocund homeward thro' the vale;</br>Now they sit beneath the shade,</br>Nature kind for love has made;</br>Breathing fresh, with harmless glee,</br>Tales of pure Simplicity.

Or we'll join the harvest train</br>Shouting jovial o'er the plain;</br>Hear them jest, and sing, and laugh,</br>While their nutbrown ale they quaff;</br>When the farmer all the while</br>Views their mirth with heartfelt smile,</br>Pleas'd to see the ripen'd year</br>Rich repay his honest care;</br>Scenes like these, best suit with thee,</br>Rural Queen, Simplicity.

Thee my Muse shall still attend;</br>Thee, the Muses fairest friend;</br>Lead her to thy sacred Power,</br>There thy softest influence shower,</br>Which inspired the bards of yore,</br>Rich in Nature's genuine lore;</br>And of late, with heavenly fire,</br>Gray and Goldsmith did inspire:</br>Happy Bard, belov'd of thee,</br>Queen of Verse, Simplicity.

Goddess, still to to thee I sue,</br>And my earliest prayer renew:</br>Give me Shenstone's gentle lay,</br>Or the tuneful lyre of Gay;</br>Or at least the Doric reed,</br>Cunningham's inferior meed,</br>Breathing strains inspired by thee,</br>His best-belov'd Simplicity.

Let me charm the nymphs and swains,</br>Pleas'd with Nature's artless strains;</br>Let me draw the silent tear,</br>From the shepherd's eye sincere;</br>Or in strains that softly move</br>Melt the maid to virtuous love;</br>Or on country festal days</br>Tune my reed their mirth to raise:</br>Thus, unenvied let me sing,</br>Jocund as the smiling Spring;</br>Happy, if approv'd by thee,</br>Rural Queen, Simplicity.</br>
